Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Transanal Irrigation with Cone Catheter versus Standard Care for Low Anterior Resection Syndrome

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to either TAI or SOC.

Participants.evidence: included patients with a low colorectal or coloanal anastomosis and a LARS score of at least 30, at least 3 months post-stoma closure.

Intervention.evidence: transanal irrigation (TAI) using a cone catheter compared to standard care (SOC)

Objective.evidence: This study assessed the effectiveness of transanal irrigation (TAI) using a cone catheter compared to standard care (SOC) in patients with major low anterior resection syndrome (LARS).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in LARS score at 3 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved through a computer-generated sequence without allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 32 were randomised (16 to TAI, 16 to SOC) between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: One patient from each group was excluded, resulting in 15 analysed per group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean LARS score decreased significantly more in the TAI group compared to SOC (p = 0.008).

Harms.evidence: Seventeen adverse events were reported in 14 patients, with none severe.

Funding.evidence: The trial was funded by Coloplast, Humlebaek, Denmark.
